welcome to my talk hiding in the clouds I've using Azure devop services to bypass Microsoft Sentinel analytic rules
I'm Brett Hawkins and I'm with ibmx Force Red before I get started um just want to note I have a link to a white
paper I posted this week on This research uh that's got full details on my research I'm about to
cover so who am I um I'm Brett I'm the capability lead on the adversary
Services team at ibmx Force Red um prior to that I was in a number of different roles both on offense and defense at
some different companies I've written a number of Open Source tools including Ado kit which I just released this week
and you'll see a demo of in this talk I've also spoken in a number of conferences uh if you're interested in
any of my public security research whether it's white papers presentations blog posts tools I have it at the link
on the the left there so how did this research come about and what were drivers on This
research first off threat actors they're continuing to Target devop systems and
Personnel um and they're doing this to conduct software supply chain attacks source code theft and to facilitate data
extration 2020 was the big one the solar wind software supply chain attack last
year uh the lapsis group compromised Microsoft's internal Azure devop system to consu source code theft and then late
last year early this year you had devops Engineers that were targeted and compromised at both circleci and last
pass to facilitate data exfiltration and then just last month Microsoft announced that a North Korean threat actor group
conducted a software supply chain attack with CyberLink Corp additionally more organizations are
continuing to adopt cloud-based services and that's caused attackers to Target these cloud-based Services as well the
big one this year was the stormo 558 threat actor group who compromised Microsoft cloudbased
services and in our adversary simulation engagements we're seeing more and more clients that are migrating from on-
premise devop systems to cloud-based specifically our team sees a lot of azure devop services and prior to this
talk there was a lack of comprehensive research and tooling on attacking the cloud-based platform and The Last Driver
there I wanted to see the effectiveness of the default Sentinel detection rules for Azure
devops I had three main goals with this research first I want to highlight the importance of testing default detection
rules second I want to inspire future devops research last I want to bring more
attention to defending cloud-based devops
platforms now this holiday season I have three takeaways or gifts for you all um so the first one you're going to learn
how to bypass the default Sentinel rules for Azure devops you're going to learn how to improve the default Sentinel
rules for a a devops and then lastly you're going to gain awareness of both privileged and unprivileged attacks
against aure devop Services what's new in this research so
there's multiple new things first off using public detection rules as a guide on defense evasion there hasn't been a
lot of talk publicly around building into your offensive methodology whenever you're attacking a system to First Look
at any publicly posted detection rules to see if there are any trivial bypasses you could use when you're attacking that
system second there haven't been any public talks that show the effectiveness of the
default Sentinel rules for aure devops additionally you're going to see a comprehensive approach in this research
attacking Azure devop services along with the new tool Ado kit that I released this week you're going to see
new methods to retrieve pipeline secrets that bypass Azure devop security controls you're also going to see a new
undocumented rest API method to perform code reconnaissance that I discovered and last you're going to see a new way
of interacting with the azer devop services rest API by the abuse of an authentication
cookie now my perspective on this I'm currently a red teamer previously I was a sock analyst I'm not any of those
those roles uh listed on the right and I definitely don't pretend to be although there's been a lack of

actual work um is included in the appendix slides of this presentation as
well in the white paper so now we're going to go ahead and

Microsoft released uh Team Foundation server or TFS and that included TFS
server and visual studio team Services then in 2019 they rebranded to
Azure devops or Ado and that included two offerings you have Azure devop server and Azure devop
Services the difference between these two offerings so Azure devop server is going to be the on- premise offering
whereas azard devop Services is the cloud-based offering I specifically focused on azard devop services for This
research now some common terminology might hear me mention throughout this talk um so an Azure tenant can have one
to many collections or organizations and then within a collection you can have one to many
projects and there's a number of different components that are included within a project the two you're going to
primarily hear me mention are Azure pipelines and Azure repos Azure repos is
the source code management piece where your source code actually lives whereas Azure pipelines is the cicd component
you also may hear me refer to a team uh team is just a set of basically project
defined members now to access Azure devop
Services you have two options the first one is a web interface and you're going to access that at dev.
a.com your organization also rest API has a rest API available and you're going to see uh

that can be applied to the rest API bunch of different components I'm not going to go into each of these Scopes
but I do have a reference Link in the white paper where Microsoft describes all of
these so in terms of security groups um security groups they're either at the project or at the collection level and
these security groups are going to basically give you different permissions to do to interact with different different components within Azure devop
services so at the project level the two privileged groups are going to be project administrators and build
administrators at the collection level project collection administrators is the
administrative group however project collection service accounts by default
is a member of project collection administrators so that is also a privilege collection group the other two
groups listed there are listed as privilege because they are able to uh interact with and retrieve build
pipeline variables and secrets in terms of logging so in Azure
devop Services if there is an auditable event so for example adding a user to a group that is going to be logged within
the audit log in the Azure devops auditing schema from there you can send
those logs via an audit log stream to a Sim such as Microsoft Sentinel and one
thing you're going to see in this research um is that I did Identify some some rooms for improvement in terms of
what is logged within the platform as it relates to the entire attacker life
cycle now if you are sending your logs to a Sim such as Microsoft Sentinel um
there are several open-source default default rule sets for many different Microsoft services within Sentinel
specifically for Azure devops there are 18 default rules that I focused on for this research to see how they performed
in terms of tax the full attacker life cycle now these are open source rule sets you can access them at the URL on
the bottom right um Azure aure Sentinel um so these are available um for you to
analyze again these are the default rule sets and what you're going to see is that in this research I did Identify

cycle as well as some trivial bypasses that are available so now that we we've kind of

another thing the attacker is going to do early on the in the attacker life cycle is persistence you want to

tax so if you have appropriate permissions you can add a user to a privileged group and that's either going to be at the project or the collection

there so another useful thing to an attacker is modifying an Azure pip line
a build pipeline so um if a uh project is using an Azure pipeline uh again
Azure pipeline is going to be the cicd component of a project if it is using an Azure pipeline there's going to be an
azure-pipelines yml file and the root of the repository now these yml files
they're configuration files uh that have different instructions within them and within Azure Dev Op Services you're
going to have a pipeline agent that runs the instructions in that configuration file now this agent can either be a
Microsoft hosted agent meaning you do not have control of that that infrastructure of of that agent or you
can have a self-hosted agent in that case you control the agent and the infrastructure you can run that on your
own infrastructure now once you modify this configuration file that's going to cause
the pipeline to run for that uh for that project and in terms of the manipulation
of this configuration file itself uh there's no you know default detections within aure devops Sentinel for aure

such kind of building off that if an attacker has gained access to Azure
devop services and has appropriate permissions to modify this Azure
pipeline configuration file and the pipeline is using a self-hosted agent an
attacker can use that to Pivot to for example an organization's on premise infrastructure now this can be
especially useful if an organization is using a self-hosted agent running on their infrastructure and it's connected

retrieving build variables and pipeline secrets so Within These Azure pipeline configuration files um you know you can
